TRSM, TRSM General
73.1 TRSM General
� General Information
The goal of the aggregate TRSM is to group all functionalities related to the transmission, including gearbox,
clutch or torque converter. The set of supported transmission types (e.g. Manual Transmission, Dual Clutch
Transmission, Automatic Transmission, Automated Manual Transmission or Continuously Variable Transmis-
sion) is con?gurable.
Some relevant information for the engine management system can be received from other ECUs instead of
being calculated internally, e.g. the transmission status (engaged gear, clutch open or closed, etc...).
73.1.1 Gear ratio
The gear ratio calculation depends on the geabox type (manual or automatic).
Two strategies are offered for MT:
Strategy 1: use of a gear sensor
Strategy 2: use of the ratio engine speed/vehicle speed
Depending on the sensor type (neutral gear sensor or all-gear sensor), the ?rst strategy allows the detection
of either the neutral gear only or all gears.
In order to avoid transient torque or transient ignition interventions at gear shifts with manual gearbox, the
gear variable GEAR is set to 0 at active clutch switch.
In case of automatic gearbox, the gear ratio is detected by using a CAN information.
73.1.2 Clutch switch
The detection of the clutch switch status is required for function management at transient conditions. It is only
necessary for cars with manual transmission (LV_AT = 0).
73.1.3 Neutral gear detection for manual shifted transmission
The detection of the neutral gear is required for Stop/Start function management. It is only necessary for cars
with manual transmission (LV_AT = 0).
73.1.4 Detection of interlock and park neutral signal
In order to activate the starter relay, the clutch pedal has to be fully pressed (interlock switch pressed) for man-
ual transmissions and the P/N signal (gear lever set to "park" or "neutral") has to be recognized for automatic
transmissions. Both information are available from the same ECU pin depending on the kind of transmis-
sion.
73.1.5 Drive train open release for stop/start
To allow automatic Stop/Start start phases, a detection of drive train open not only based on the interlock and
park/neutral signal but also on plausibility checks is realized inside this module.
73.1.6 Clutch switch diagnosis
This module performs the diagnosis of the two clutch switches. This is valid only in case of manual transmis-
sion.
The following diagnosis are performed:
- diagnosis of clutch pedal value received from Parking-Brake-ECU via CAN
- plausibility diagnosis between clutch switch and clutch pedal value
- plausibility diagnosis of clutch switch pressed

TRSM, TRSM General
- plausibility diagnosis of clutch switch released
- shortcut to ground diagnosis of the interlock switch
- shortcut to plus diagnosis of the interlock switch without EPB clutch pedal value
- shortcut to plus diagnosis of the interlock switch with EPB clutch pedal value
- diagnosis of neutral gear start release signal
73.1.7 Park neutral switch diagnosis
This module performs the diagnosis of the park/neutral signal (automatic transmission). This is valid only in
case of automatic transmission.
The following diagnosis are performed:
- park neutral switch diagnosis short circuit to ground
- park neutral switch diagnosis short circuit to plaus and open circuit
73.1.8 Neutral gear detection sensor diagnosis
This module performs the diagnosis of the neutral gear sensor. This is valid only in case of manual transmis-
sion.
73.1.9 Gear ratio diagnosis
The transmission is sending its gear ratio via CAN. For vehicle cruise control and drivetrain manager functions,
a plausibility diagnosis is done. This is valid only in case of automatic transmission.
73.1.10 Torque reserve for transmission
All torque reserve requests which are needed for transmission are resumed in this function. The central output
of this module is an input to the torque reserve coordination.
73.1.11 Torque request for manual gear shift
In order to support smooth manual gear shifting when driving with cruise control, it is possible for the cruise
control to activate this engine speed controller.
73.1.12 TRSM Con?guration Data
The con?guration of the TRSM functionalities is provided inside this module.

TRSM, TRSM Con?guration data
This document describes the general rules for de?nition of the con?guration data for the transmission aggre-
gate TRSM.
Using ENUM_IDX_xx_TYP and NC_NR_xx_TYP (xx = GB or TRANS), it is possible to replace the numerical index
by strings in the display identi?ers of some calibration datas. Thus, it is possible to mix data across projects
even when different combinations of gearboxes are supported.
Example for MT, CVT and DCT gearboxes:
NLF_CONF_TRANS_TYP = 0001 1001
NC_NR_TRANS_TYP = 0 + 0 + 0 + 1 + 1 + 0 + 0 + 1 = 3
This means array maps de?ned using NC_NR_TRANS_TYP have an array size of 3.
ENUM_IDX_TRANS_TYP is de?ned as follows:
SW numerical index A2L (INCA) required index
0 MT
1 CVT
2 DCT
3 Not used
4 Not used
5 Not used
6 Not used
7 Not used
The maps will be named as follows:
Internal SW name A2L (INCA) Name
ID_FAC_IVS_MASS_VEH[0] ID_FAC_IVS_MASS_VEH[MT]
ID_FAC_IVS_MASS_VEH[1] ID_FAC_IVS_MASS_VEH[CVT]
ID_FAC_IVS_MASS_VEH[2] ID_FAC_IVS_MASS_VEH[DCT]
Application Hint:
The determination of IDX_TRANS_TYP in the variant coding / transmission module must be consistent with
the names speci?ed here. For this example, IDX_TRANS_TYP = 1 shall be determine inside the variant coding.
De?nition of NLF_CONF_TRANS_TYP
Bit Meaning
0 MT
1 ATC
2 AMT
3 CVT
4 DCT
5 MT_4WD
6 ATC_4WD

� General Information
The purpose of this module is to provide standardized inputs to the other modules of the transmission ag-
gregate and to provide backward compatibility for the modules outside transmission aggregate. Creation of
some of the standardized interfaces is done here temporarily until other functions mostly outside - some also
inside - the transmission aggregate provide them.
Hint: the subsystem OPM shall be executed before all other TRSM modules and the subsystem OPM1 shall be
executed after all other TRSM modules.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST
Activation: always
Deactivation: never
Recurrence: 10MS

� General Information
The gearbox control unit ETCU may request an increased idle speed. This function checks and limits the gear-
box request and its gradient, substitutes it when necessary or inhibits the request entirely. The functionality
described in this speci?cation is not limited to increasing requests, but it is not used for decreasing requests.
The reason is, that the engine speed setpoint calculation coordinates the output of this function with other
requests in an increasing manner only.

TRSM, Gearbox engine speed request for idle speed controller
The functionality has two main outputs:
1. A binary information, if an idle speed control for gearbox is requested
2. The engine speed requested by gearbox for idle speed controller, if a request is present
The second part of the function provides the action for the gearbox end-of-line test. It passes the gearbox
request sent during test execution to the garage end-of-line function along with the transmission aggregate
speci?c enable condition created inside this speci?cation.

73.5.2 Standard operation
The functionality executed during standard operation is structured into two parts: The calculation of the target
state which makes use of the enable conditions and the calculation of the idle speed setpoint for transmis-
sion.
The target state is
a) the original request by the gearbox in case of regular operation, for security reasons permanently limited
depending on the vehicle state
b) like a) but additionally limited by a constant upper limit in case of a preliminary error, i.e. a symptom
c) a constant substitute value in case of error
d) complete inhibition of the function if the enable conditions are not ful?lled. Enabling the function only makes
sense as long as the ignition key is not turned off. For automatic gearboxes enabling of the functionality can
be made dependent on the state of the converter clutch, e.g. to inhibit increased idle speed requests during
gear shift processes, where a gearbox torque intervention might be effective.
All states except ?inhibited? lead to an idle speed request for gearbox, and the corresponding output ?ag of
this function will be set. Only in this case the idle speed request by the gearbox will be considered in the
coordination of the idle speed setpoint.
Currently versions of the coordination of the idle speed setpoint however do not yet use this ?ag, such that the
engine speed request by the gearbox has to be set to a value without effect. This passive or inhibited status
can be reached, if the idle speed setpoint for the gearbox is 100rpm below the global idle speed setpoint of
the last recurrence. This is a failsafe solution for backward compatibility with current versions of the idle speed
control.
Additionally, the idle speed requested by gear box can be set by calibration during coasting phases.
To avoid steps in engine speed and torque on the gearbox input shaft due to changes in state, caused espe-
cially by discrete changes in the enable conditions, the engine speed gradient is limited in both directions.

73.5.3 Action de?nition for gearbox end-of-line test
The standard interface between the garage end of line aggregate GEOL and the aggregates that are involved
with tests, here the transmission aggregate TRSM, is an action call. The action delivers an enable ?ag as well
as the necessary physical values to perform the test.
The enable ?ag is constantly true. This is a historic setting, which should be improved, because a test only
should be enabled, if the raw physical value sends valid signals. Additionally the entire end-of-line strategy
should give a feedback to the testing person that distinguishes between communication errors, i.e. CAN not
functional or connecting cable not working, and test intrinsic errors like gearbox sending signals with invalid
content.

TRSM, Gearbox engine speed request for idle speed controller
The physical value is the idle speed requested by gearbox control unit from CAN standardized in intersystem
communication INTC without modi?cations.
An end-of-line test is not executed during normal driving, such that the idle speed requested by gearbox
control unit can be used twice, for the increase of the idle speed during regular operation as well as for any
engine speed, even those higher than idle speed, during an end-of-line test. During the end-of-line-test the
normal idle speed increase request needs to be disabled.

Figure 73.6.4:
73.6.2.2 Gear detection parameters for manual gearbox
The ratio vehicle speed to engine speed (VS_N)is helpful to detect open drive train or neutral gear, as in
this case VS_N presents big oscillations and gradients engine speed can change with out impact in vehicle
speed-.
So for manual transmission
following calculations are performed:
- Filtering of the ratio vehicle speed to engine speed (VS_N) and gradient of this ratio.
- Drive off detection based on the requested torque by driver or idle speed controller. This information supports
the detection of an open drive train.
- Open drive detection, using the gradient of the vehicle speed to engine speed ratio, idle speed information
and torque requested
In case of automatic transmissions these calculations are normally not necessary and all these values are set
to 0. But it?s pssible by means of calibration to activate the gear detection for manual transmission in vehicles
with automatic transmission

Three different methods can be used for detection of open drive train. The customer can select which of the
methods must be used.

TRSM, Gear detection (Appl. Inc.)
An open drive train situation occurs when:
- The clutch is open
- The clutch is slipping
- No gear is engaged
The cluch switch signal only is not reliable to determinate if the clutch is still slipping or it?s already transmitting
all the power from engine to transmission.
Additionally, the vehicle speed to engine speed ratio can not determine accurately the engaged gear in case
of the driver engages neutral gear while the car is still moving. Therefore 3 methods support the detection of
open drive train.

Figure 73.6.12:
73.6.2.2.3.4 Open drive train determination strategy at gearshift without clutch
Open drive train is detected in case of drive shifts to neutral gear without using the clutch and/or the car keeps
moving without engaged gear.
The open drive state is set if the gradient of the vehicle speed-engine speed ratio increases above a thresh-
old.
The open drive state is kept as long as these conditions are not present:
- A low vehicle speed to engine speed ratio with not active idle speed controller
- A low vehicle speed to engine speed ratio with active idle speed controller and a high torque request
- A low vehicle speed.

and in the method 2 for open drive detection in case of manual transmission.

engaged gear for cruise control uses the information provided by the automatic gearbox or the calculation
done for manual transmission.

73.6.2.4 Transmission ratio based on engaged gear
In case of manual transmission, the transmission ratio is calculated based on the calculated engaged gear.
In case of automatic transmission, the transmission ratio is calculated based on the transmission ratio from
CAN (including a backlash ?ltering). In case of CAN error, the calculation based on engaged gear is used as
backup solution.

TRSM, Gear detection
� Import actions:
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(IN <PRM_FID>, OUT <PRM_LV_PRMS>)
� General Information
In case of manual transmission, the determination of the actual gear is executed using either the ratio between
engine speed and wheel speed or a gear sensor. Several functions need a debounced gear information in case
of closed drivetrain. This variable is calculated as GEAR_AJ.
In case of automatic transmission, the actual gear is determined using the transmitted gear information from
transmission control unit. If the vehicle isn?t running or when the transmitted gear is the reverse gear, then the
gear is set equal to seperated constants.
Additional, a debounced gear is calculated in case of gear shift.
Drive train engaged active (LV_DT=1) means drive train is closed, engine torque is transmitted to the wheels
and the vehicle is running. With engaged gear it is normally not necessary to have an aggressive idle speed
control. The only exception is a sudden breaking at slowly moving vehicle with engaged gear. In this case it
is necessary to switch to the strong PD parameter map of the idle speed control to avoid idle speed break-
down.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST
Activation: always
Deactivation: never
Recurrence: 10MS

INTER shall be always calibrated. Thus, a hysteresis between the gears is realized.

detection and whether a ?nished sensor adaption has to be con?rmed or not before use.

73.7.2.5 Gear from CAN
For automatic transmission, the gear from gearbox control unit is used.
For continuously variable transmission, the gear ratio from gearbox control unit is used to determine the
gear.
When the vehicle isn?t running or when the reverse gear is detected, some substitute values are used. Oth-
erwise, the gear is set to 0 for continuously variable transmission when the gear lever is equal to ?PRKG? or
?NEUT?.

Figure 73.7.9:
73.7.2.7 Drive train engaged calculation
Drive train engaged active means drive train is closed, engine torque is transmitted to the wheels and the
vehicle is running.
Additionally, drivetrain disengaged can be detected when the gear information has changed. Indeed, a change
of the gear information induces that the drivetrain has been opened. This additional condition is particularly
useful to avoid the detection of an engaged drivetrain when a gear is wrongly detected (for example, during
coasting phases with gear lever in neutral).

� General Information
Bei einem Betrieb mit "Start-Stop"-Funktionalit�t werden erh�hte Anforderungen an die
Verf�gbarkeit der Startersteuerungsfunktionalit�t gestellt. So muss der Motor nicht nur
h�u?ger gestartet werden, sondern bei Startanforderungen vom Start-Stopp-Koordinator auch
dann, wenn der Fahrer das Kupplungspedal nicht voll durchdr�ckt bzw. den W�hlhebel nicht
in die Park- oder Neutralposition gebracht hat.
Das bedeutet, dass das Triebstrang-offen-Freigabesignal auch dann gesetzt sein muss, wenn
sich bei Fahrzeugen mit Handschaltgetrieben der Gangwahlhebel in der Leer- oder
Neutralgangstellung be?ndet bzw. bei Fahrzeugen mit Automatikgetrieben der Triebstrang
tats�chlich getrennt ist - unabh�ngig von der W�hlhebelposition.
Bei Fahrzeugen mit Automatikgetrieben kann nur das Getriebesteuerger�t eine solche
erweiterte Triebstrang-offen-Freigabe erzeugen. Die Startersteuerung fordert ggf. lediglich
eine Triebstrang-Offen-Freigabe auch bei eingelegter Fahrstufe �ber CAN an, die MGSHardware ist hiervon
somit nicht betroffen.
Bei Fahrzeugen mit Handschaltgetrieben hingegen muss ein zus�tzlicher Neutralgangsensor
eingef�hrt werden. Das MSG wertet diesen aus und erzeugt in einer getrennten Endstufe ein
Freigabesignal analog zum Interlockschalter, das dann mit dem Signal eben dieses
Interlockschalters elektrisch verodert wird.

73.9.2 Standard operation
Das MSG muss �ber einen eigenen Eingangspin das analoge Ausgangssignal eines
Neutralgangsensors (NGS - Neutral Gear Sensor) einlesen und �ber Analog/Digital-Wandler
dem Controller zur Verf�gung stellen. Anstelle des Einlesens und Wandelns eines
Analogsignales kann auch das Einlesen eines PWM-Signales gesondert vereinbart werden.
Bei erkanntem Neutralgang im Falle eines Motorstopps wird eine zus�tzliche
Endstufe angesteuert, die parallel zum Interlocksensor eine Freigabe zur Starteransteuerung
geben kann.

73.9.2.3.2 Neutralgang-Roherkennung
Sobald die NGS-Spannung in einen Schaltwinkel umgerechnet wird, kann der zum
Neutralgang geh�rige Schaltwinkel gelernt werden (s.u.). Ist auch diese Schaltwinkeladaption
abgeschlossen, kann auf einen eingelegten Neutralgang geschlossen werden, wenn der
aktuelle Schaltwinkel in einem gewissen Bereich um den angelernten Neutralgang-
Schaltwinkel liegt.
Das entsprechende Neutralgang-erkannt-Signal braucht im Normalfall nur leicht entprellt
werden. Bei Beginn einer Starteransteuerung hingegen ist eine gr��ere Entprellung
vorzusehen, da der Neutralgangsensor in der N�he des Starters verbaut ist und damit beim
Starten einem starken, wechselnden Magnetfeld ausgesetzt ist. So k�nnte es ggf. zu
unberechtigten Startabbr�chen wegen Beein?ussung des Sensors kommen.

73.9.2.3.3 Neutralgang-Ausgabe
Da von einem erkannten Neutralgang nicht nur die Koordination des "Start/Stop"-Betriebes
abh�ngt, sondern auch die Startfreigabe inkl. Hardware-Freigabe, unterliegt die Erkennung
erh�hten Sicherheitsanforderungen. So soll erst, wenn in einem Fahrzyklus das Ergebnis der
Neutralgangroherkennung in beide Richtungen plausibilisiert werden konnte (aktives wie
passives Neutralgang-erkannt-Signal, s.u.), eine Freigabe des Neutralgangsensors erfolgen.
Diese dient in der Startersteuerung wiederum als Voraussetzung zur Freigabe des
"Start/Stop"-Betriebes.

So soll erst, wenn in einem Fahrzyklus das Ergebnis der
Neutralgangroherkennung in beide Richtungen plausibilisiert werden konnte (aktives wie
passives Neutralgang-erkannt-Signal, s.u.), eine Freigabe des Neutralgangsensors erfolgen.
Diese dient in der Startersteuerung wiederum als Voraussetzung zur Freigabe des
"Start/Stop"-Betriebes.

73.9.2.5.2 Plausibilisierung Schubbedingungen
Die Schuberkennung basiert dabei darauf, dass trotz einer Motordrehzahl oberhalb der
Leerlaufdrehzahl das abgegebene Motormoment unterhalb des Leerlaufbedarfs liegt. Je nach
Fahrer und Verkehrslage kommt es ggf. jedoch nur selten zu gen�gend langen Schubphasen.
So ist nur ein fehlerfreier Ausgang dieser Plausibilisierung oder der Zugplausibilisierung eine
der Voraussetzungen, um den NGS �berhaupt freizugeben.

Verdrehwinkels der Handschaltgetriebe-Schaltwelle (s.o.). Offset und Amplitude h�ngen

des Signals erforderlich ist.

gabe) getrennt voneinander gelernt (High-/ Lowpegeladaption).

umgerechnet werden. Bei sicher eingelegtem Neutralgang, d.h. im Stand bei laufendem
Motor, wird schlie�lich auch der errechnete Neutralgang-Schaltwinkel adaptiert.

73.9.2.6.1 Freigabe High/Low
Um das Risiko von Fehladaptionen z.B. durch Halten des Schalthebels durch den Fahrer in
einer untypischen Position gering zu halten, sollen High- und Lowpegel-Adaption erst bei
station�rer Sensorspannung freigegeben werden. Um weiterhin den Ein?uss von trotz allem
nicht sicher auszuschlie�enden Fehladaptionen (z.B. bei durch Hindernisse im
Schaltgassenbereich leicht verklemmtem Schalthebel) gering zu halten, sollen die Adaptionen ereignisentprellt
nur einmal je sicher festgestelltem geraden bzw. ungeraden Gang statt?nden. Um aber auch eine schnellen
Abschluss der Adaptionen und damit eine z�gige Verf�gbarkeit der Neutralgangerkennung zu gew�hrleisten
(nach M�glichkeit vor Fahrzeugauslieferung an den Kunden und ohne erh�hten Aufwand bei der Inbetrieb-
nahme am Bandende), sollen die Adaptionen bis zu ihrem Abschluss kontinuierlich ablaufen. Schlie�lich darf
die Adaption nur bei Batteriespannungen oberhalb einer gewissen Schwelle freigegeben werden, da bei zu
geringen Bordnetzspannungen die Stromversorgung des NGS durch das MSG nicht sichergestellt ist.

ACTION_TRSM_ResetNeutGearNvmy() Mode: O
Action to reset the variables in non volatile memory used for neutral gear determination; reset-variables used for neutral gear sensor
must be stored directly in NVMY
� General Information
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: at reset and at transition of IGK from OFF to ON:
LV_RST_NEUT_GEAR_NVMYn?1= 0
at reset:
LV_STATE_ANG_NEUT_GEAR_ACQ = NLC_ANG_NEUT_GEAR_ACT
LV_STATE_STST_FCT_NEUT_GEAR = NLC_STATE_STST_FCT_ACT
LV_ERR_CLU_SWI_NEUT_GEAR = !(ACTION_FARM_GetPermission (IN
<NC_FID_CLU_SWI_NEUT_GEAR>, OUT <PRM_LV_PRMS>))
Activation: all engine states
Deactivation: -
Recurrence: 10ms
� Function Description
If LV_RST_NEUT_GEAR_NVMYn?1= 1
Then
LV_RST_NEUT_GEAR_NVMYn = 0
Endif
LV_RST_NEUT_GEAR_NVMYn?1= LV_RST_NEUT_GEAR_NVMYn
LV_ERR_CLU_SWI_NEUT_GEAR = !(ACTION_FARM_GetPermission ( IN <NC_FID_CLU_SWI_
NEUT_GEAR>, OUT <PRM_LV_PRMS>))
LV_STST_ENG_ST_NEUT_GEAR = LV_STST_ST_REQ // Start-request by STST-manager
LV_NEUT_GEAR_SENS_ERR_GEAR = !(ACTION_FARM_GetPermission ( IN <NC_FID_GEAR_SENS_
ERR_GEAR>, OUT <PRM_LV_PRMS>))
IF LC_GEAR_SEL_STST_RLS = 1
TTEN
GEAR_STST_RLS = GEAR
ELSE
GEAR_STST_RLS = GEAR_GR
ENDIF

� Import actions:
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(IN <PRM_FID>, OUT <PRM_LV_PRMS>)
ACTION_INFR_GetCluSwi(OUT <PRM_LV_CLU_SWI>)
� General Information
Detection of the clutch status is required for function management at transient conditions. It is only necessary
for cars with manual transmission (LV_MT = 1).
LV_CLU_SWI represents the status of the HW clutch switch (true for closed switch).
Via the switch LC_CS_DET_MOD it can be selected, if LV_CS is determined via the PIN-Value (=0) or via the
clutch pedal way information (=1).
At detection of closed HW clutch switch (LV_CLU_SWI = 1) the timer T_CLU_SWI is started.
This may be delayed using the debounce strategy if activated, which needs minimum 3 times sequently same
values of clutch switch.
The ?ag for open clutch (LV_CLU_OPEN = 1) will be set if driver passive is detected (LV_CT = 1) before the timer
T_CLU_SWI reaches its maximum value C_T_MAX_CLU_SWI. LV_CLU_OPEN and the counter T_CLU_SWI will be
reset at change of LV_CLU_SWI from 1 to 0.
LV_CS is identical to LV_CLU_OPEN and is only provided for interface reasons.
Variant with Clutch switch modulation signal via EPB-CAN:
If a variant with Clutch switch modulation signal via EPB-CAN is used (NC_CLU_SWI_EPB_ENA == 1) the clutch
switch signal via EPB-CAN is used. This signal can be inverted via LC_CLU_SWI_EPB_IVS.
If a CAN-Error is pending the HW-Switch information is used for the clutch information.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST
Activation: LV_MT == 1
Deactivation: LV_MT == 0
Recurrence: 10MS

73.11.2 Standard operation
The functionality includes:
- Clutch switch signal using variant with or without "Kupplungsmodulationsbereich" (clutch switch modulation
range)
- the raw clutch open signal using clutch switch signal or clutch pedal movement
- a debounce of choosen clutch signal if selected
- a timer counting time since clutch signal reports open clutch if calibrated
- the ?nal system clutch signal.

73.11.2.6 Clutch open calculation
The clutch signal is determined.
Clutch open is ?rst detected when timer has elapsed and throttle is closed.
Throttle closed condition can be neglected via calibration.
The ?ag clutch open is reset only in condition of safe detection for closed clutch (switch=0).
In other conditions the current value is kept.

TRSM, Detection of interlock and park neutral signal
� Import actions:
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(IN <PRM_FID>, OUT <PRM_LV_PRMS>)
ACTION_INFR_GetPnCluSwi2(OUT <PRM_LV_PN_CLU_SWI_2>)
� General Information
In order to activate the starter relay, the clutch pedal has to be fully pressed (interlock switch pressed) for
manual transmissions and the P/N signal (gear lever set to "park" or "neutral") has to be recognized for automatic
transmissions. Both information are available from the same ECU pin depending on the kind of transmission.
As backup solution for calculation of the status of the HW interlock or park/neutral switch, a CAN signal from
the vehicle electrics message is used.
An additional signal is provided when the interlock switch or P/N signal is recognized and the powerstage for
the drivetrain open release for StopStart is not set.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: at ECU reset:
LV_PN_CLU_SWI_2 = 0
T_PN_CLU_SWI_2_HW = 0
LV_PN_CLU_SWI_2_HW = 0
LV_CLU_SWI_2 = 0
LV_PN = 0
LV_SWI_NEUT_GEAR = 0
Activation: LV_IGK == 1 OR LC_PN_CLU_SWI_2_DET_ENA == 1
Deactivation: if activation not true
Recurrence: 10ms
� Function Description
IF(1) LV_STR_CONF == 1 and LV_STATE_STR_CLC == 1
THEN(1) ACTION_INFR_GetPnCluSwi2(OUT <PRM_LV_PN_CLU_SWI_2>)
IF(2) LC_PN_CLU_SWI_2_IVS == 0
THEN(2) LV_PN_CLU_SWI_2 = PRM_LV_PN_CLU_SWI_2
ELSE(2) LV_PN_CLU_SWI_2 = NOT(PRM_LV_PN_CLU_SWI_2)
ENDIF(2)
ELSE(1) IF(3) LV_CAN_ACT_VEH_TYPE_PQX == 1 and ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(IN<NC_
FID_PN_CLU_SWI_2_VECU_CAN>,OUT<LV_PRMS_TMP>) == 1
THEN(3) LV_PN_CLU_SWI_2 = LV_ST_ENA_VECU_CAN
ELSE(3) LV_PN_CLU_SWI_2 = 0
ENDIF(3)
ENDIF(1)
// TurnOffDelay of LV_DT_OPEN_NEUT_GEAR
// T_PN_CLU_SWI_2 represents the delayed LV_DT_OPEN_NEUT_GEAR
IF(4) LV_DT_OPEN_NEUT_GEAR == 1
THEN(4) T_PN_CLU_SWI_2_HW = C_T_PN_CLU_SWI_2_HW
ELSE(4) IF(5) T_PN_CLU_SWI_2_HW > 0
THEN(5) T_PN_CLU_SWI_2_HW- - //Timer decrement
ENDIF(5)
ENDIF(4)

25941Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

Copyright �Continental AG. Transmittal, reproduction, dissemination and/or editing of this document as well as utilisation of its contents and communication thereof to others without

TRSM, Detection of interlock and park neutral signal
// LV_PN_CLU_SWI_2_HW is set, if the Hardware pin shows a activated interlock-
or pn-switch and the drive train open powerstage is not active
IF(6) LV_PN_CLU_SWI_2 == 1 and T_PN_CLU_SWI_2_HW == 0
THEN(6) LV_PN_CLU_SWI_2_HW = 1
ELSE(6) LV_PN_CLU_SWI_2_HW = 0
ENDIF(6)
IF(7) LV_AT = 1
THEN(7) LV_CLU_SWI_2 = 0
IF(8) LV_PN_CLU_SWI_2 == 1
THEN(8) LV_PN = 1
ELSE(8) LV_PN = 0
ENDIF(8)
ELSE(7) LV_PN = 0
IF(9) LV_PN_CLU_SWI_2 == 1 and LV_DT_OPEN_NEUT_GEAR == 0
THEN(9) LV_CLU_SWI_2 = 1
ELSE(9) LV_CLU_SWI_2 = 0
ENDIF(9)
ENDIF(7)
IF(10) LV_PN_CLU_SWI_2 == 1 and LV_DT_OPEN_NEUT_GEAR == 1
THEN(10) LV_SWI_NEUT_GEAR = 1
ELSE(10) LV_SWI_NEUT_GEAR = 0
ENDIF(10)

earlier than the physical change inside the gearbox. In this case, the old value shall be held for a calibratable
time.

Figure 73.14.12:
73.14.2.8 Activation of slow torque for gearbox torque intervention including substitute values
In case of PQx platform, the slow torque request is activated in case of launch control or per calibration.
The limitation of the slow torque request (based on fast torque request divided by the ef?ciency at minimum
ignition angle) can be bypassed by calibration for both sources of intervention. The reasons are different
depending on the use case:
? for launch control, the bypass allows a torque reduction with ignition angle and cylinder shut-off only. In
this way, the throttle remains open and the intake air can be turbocharged
? for calibrated activation, the bypass allows quicker gear shifts (either using a torque reserve at decreasing
request or a torque overshooting at the beginning of increasing request)

Figure 73.14.13:
73.14.2.9 Slow torque for gearbox torque intervention including substitute values
In case of PQx platform, the slow torque request is internally calculated and allows different strategies:
? equal to a constant value (for launch control)
? equal to the fast torque request (independently for increasing and decreasing requests) with the option
of a calibratable offset depending on the use case (to provide either a torque reserve at decreasing
request or a slow torque overshooting at the beginning of increasing request)
If it is used, the limitation of the slow torque request (based on fast torque request divided by the ef?ciency at
minimum ignition angle) is calculated into "Gearbox intervention" module.

� Import actions:
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(IN <PRM_FID>, OUT <PRM_LV_PRMS>)
ACTION_INFR_SetNeutGear(IN <PRM_STATE_NEUT_GEAR>)
� General Information
During Stop/Start start phases, the starter relays have to detect an open drivetrain. However, this is only
possible when the interlock is put to ground. For this reason and since it is not required from the driver to
activate this interlock (for example by fully pressing the clutch) during the automatic start phases, the same
power stage is put to ground by the action-call of this function after detection of an open drivetrain.
Additionally, the output of the function is used into the starter relay software module.
If the ECU is equipped with a reset resistant microprocessor, the triggering of the power stage is needless and
only the software path is enough to ful?ll the start conditions.

73.16.2.2 Drivetrain open release for automatic transmission
The drivetrain open release for automatic transmission is set when at least one of the following conditions is
ful?lled:
- brake signal set
- autohold function keeps the vehicle stopped
- electrical parking brake keeps the vehicle stopped
- follow-to-stop function keeps the vehicle stopped
- gear lever set to P or N

73.16.2.3 Drivetrain open release for manual transmission
The drivetrain open release for manual transmission is set when the following conditions are ful?lled:
- starter relay is activated
- ?rst clutch switch is pressed
- either:
- neutral gear is engaged
- change of mind is detected (in this case, the second clutch switch has to be pressed and the drivetrain
open release has not to be set to avoid a deadlock).
The drivetrain open release for manual transmission is reset when at leaset one of the following conditions is
ful?lled:
- ?rst clutch switch is not pressed
- maximum time for drivetrain open release is reached

TRSM, Clutch diagnosis
?Funktionslastenheft f�r PN_Signal_Plausibilisierung?
xxA0GDxx.00x
The diagnosis is done in two variants which can be selected via LF_CONF_CLU_DIAG.
LF_CONF_CLU_DIAG.bit0 == 0
No clutch pedal sensor is available. All diagnoses are done with the information given by the clutch- and the
interlock-switch.
LF_CONF_CLU_DIAG.bit1 == 1
A clutch pedal sensor is available. The diagnoses which are done with the information given by the clutch- and
the interlock-switch are additionally veri?ed via the pedal value.
Con?guration of LF_CONF_CLU_DIAG:
Bit_0: Pedal value sensor and pedal value available
Bit_1: Interlock switch short to ground second diagnosis active
Bit_2: CAN-Signal diagnosis activated
Bit_3: Interlock switch available
Each diagnosis can be activated via the according switch.

Figure 73.17.12:
73.17.2.2.2 Test, clutch okay
The signal of the clutch- and of the interlock switch as well as the pedal way can be considered as plausible if
both possible states (pedal not activated, pedal activated) were pending for a given time.
This function is active for the variants with and without clutch pedal way information. It is adapted via the con-
?guration of clutch diagnosis LF_CONF_CLU_DIAG.
The ?ag LV_CLU_SWI_OK is reset at ECU-Initialization and at the occurrence of a clutch- or interlock switch
error.
If the bit was reset by an error it can only be set after a KL-15-Reset.

Figure 73.17.13:
73.17.2.2.2.1 Clutch correctly activated and clutch correctly not activated
Clutch correctly activated is detected when all available clutch information shows clutch open for a calibratable
time.
Clutch correctly not activated is detected when all available clutch information shows clutch closed for a cali-
bratable time.
For each driving cycle, if a clutch error is detected, both clutch correctly activated signal and clutch correctly
not activated signal are reset and can only be set again after an IGKON.

Figure 73.17.18:
73.17.2.2.4 Diagnosis of clutch switch pedal value
The conditions of the given signals, which point at an implausible clutch switch signal or an implausible pedal
way information, will cause the same error reaction. Therefore, at an implausibility, it is not distinguished which
error has caused this error reaction.
Because the values of the given signals can be seen in the service test tool the reason for the error can easily
be detected.
An error is detected if implausibility between the clutch switch signal and the pedal way information occurs
for a given time.
The error is reset if after a KL-15-Reset the LV_CLU_SWI_OK bit is set.

Figure 73.17.20:
73.17.2.2.5.1 Detection of gear changes for calculation of CS symptoms via gear changes
If the gear is changed form 2nd gear directly to 6th gear, the gear information counts the intermediate gears
too.
For example: Gear changed from 2nd to 6th means changes 2- ->3- ->4- ->5- ->6
The function for the detection of gear changes without activated clutch switch or with always activated clutch
switch (defective clutch switch detection) would detect 4 gear changes with a defective clutch switch sensor.

TRSM, Clutch diagnosis
73.17.2.2.5.2 Plausibility diagnosis of clutch switch pressed
If there is
- no clutch switch signal error
- no interlock switch signal error
- the condition considering the vehicle speed
- the condition considering the engine speed
- the battery voltage condition for functions needed at start
ful?lled for a given time then, a counter is incremented at every gear change.
The counter is reset at a falling edge of the clutch switch signal.
The error is detected if the counter exceeds the de?nable threshold and thus a number of gear changes
without a kicked clutch are detected.
If no error is detected, the error value of the diagnosis via pedal value is feed through.
The error is reset if after a KL-15-Reset the LV_CLU_SWI_OK bit is set.

TRSM, Clutch diagnosis
The error is detected if the counter exceeds the de?nable threshold and thus a number of gear changes
without a kicked clutch are detected.
If no error is detected, the error value of the diagnosis via pedal value is feed through.
The error is reset if after a KL-15-Reset the LV_CLU_SWI_OK bit is set.

73.17.2.2.6 Interlock switch - Shortcut to ground diagnosis
If there is no clutch switch signal error pending and the clutch switch shows "clutch not kicked" but the interlock
switch shows "clutch kicked" are this information implausible. This implausibility leads after a given time to the
setting of the ?ag "Interlock switch short cut to ground error".
If the variant with the pedal value information via CAN is selected:
If there is no CAN error the second variant waits until a valid CAN-Signal is detected. Thus it can be distin-
guished if there was an implausible clutch switch signal or an implausible interlock switch signal.
In the pedal value variant additionally a constant shown "clutch kicked" interlock switch signal is detected. If the
clutch switch signal and the interlock switch signal show "clutch fully kicked", but the signal way information
shows only an activated clutch switch.
This check can be deactivated via the con?guration of clutch diagnosis LF_CONF_CLU_DIAG.bit1.

73.17.2.2.7 Interlock switch - Shortcut to plus diagnosis
At the detection of a "never kicked" showing interlock switch it has to be distinguished between the two real-
ization versions. In the ?rst function the pedal value information can be used. In the second variant the pedal
value information is not available.
Which function is used is selected via the con?guration of clutch diagnosis LF_CONF_CLU_DIAG.

Figure 73.17.28:
73.17.2.2.7.1 Detection Interlock SCP via pedal value information
A "never kicked" showing interlock switch signal can be surely be detected via the pedal way information.
An error can be considered as detected if the clutch switch signal shows a kicked clutch and the pedal way
exceeds the interlock switch threshold for a given time.

Figure 73.17.29:
73.17.2.2.7.2 Calculation of Interlock SCP without pedal value information
It is not possible to detect a "never kicked" showing interlock switch signal. But the error can be considered as
detected, if at a given number of start requests the clutch switch shows "clutch kicked" but the interlock switch
shows "clutch not kicked".
The counter for the start requests value is stored in the NVMY.
The counter is reset after the diagnosis has ?nished with a "FAIL". This ensures that, after an IGKON, "FAIL"
will not be set immediately but only if the counter reaches the calibratable threshold again after a renewed
debouncing of the symptom.
The counter is also reset as soon as the interlock switch is seen as pressed.

Figure 73.17.30:
73.17.2.2.8 Determination of interlock signal for release of automatic start
The automatic start release signal is generated via the hardware interlock switch signal and plausibilized via
the CAN-EPB-Pedal way (if available).
A manual start has to be allowed, even
? the interlock switch signal is erroneous or not plausible
? the clutch switch signal is erroneous or not plausible
? the CAN-EPB-Pedal way signal is erroneous or not plausible
A vehicle start has to be possible if an interlock switch signal is recognized.

TRSM, Clutch diagnosis
73.17.2.3.1 Generation of test impulse for SCP/OC detection of power stage for drive-train-open-release
A short cut plus or open load of the power stage for drive-train-open-release can only be tested if it is active
activated. This activation occurs normally during the restart request by the start/stop coordinator, therefore a
start release can not be preformed if a SCP/OC is pending.
Because of that a check for SCP/OC has to be performed before the ?rst start/stop phase.
This check has only be done once in a driving cycle, therefore the ?ag LV_NEUT_GEAR_ACR_DIAG_DC is set if
the test impulse was completely performed. (T_DUR_NEUT_GEAR_ACR_DIAG has count down to zero)
If the conditions for the impulse are ful?lled (Cond.A and Cond.B) and the impulse was not completely executed
within this driving cycle LV_NEUT_GEAR_ACR_DIAG is set for the time C_T_DUR_NEUT_GEAR_ACR_DIAG.
If the set conditions vanish during the test impulse execution the impulse is reset and newly started if the
conditions are ful?lled again.

TRSM, Gearbox intervention diagnosis
� Import actions:
ACTION_ERRM_ResultDiag(IN <PRM_IDX_ERR>, IN <PRM_STATE_DGO>, OUT <PRM_STATE_FIL>)
ACTION_ERRM_VarCod(IN <PRM_IDX_ERR>, IN <PRM_LV_ERR_DEAC>)
� General Information
The main results of this function are:
1. The diagnosis based on vehicle acceleration
2. The diagnosis based on torque integral, especially for increasing intervention
3. The residual torque integral available for gearbox intervention, designated as feedback to the gearbox
via intersystem communication.
The results of the diagnostics are designated to be accessed via error management.

Figure 73.19.9:
73.19.2.4.1 Integrator core
The integral increases based on the torque setpoint (with external interventions) minus the inertia torque and
the maximum between the torque losses and the torque request after transient torque function.
The integral decreases based on the sum of the inertia torque and the torque losses limited by a constant.
This ensures that the integral will decrease at least with that constant.
If the conditions for increasing the torque integral are not ful?lled, the integral can only be decreased.

73.19.2.4.2 Torque integral based enable condition for torque losses
The diagnosis based on torque integral enables gearbox increasing intervention only if the integral has not
reached its maximum capacity. Once the increasing intervention has been disabled, it can be enabled only
if the integral has been completely emptied and a non-increasing request is read from both gearbox torque
intervention and gearbox engine speed control.

� General Information
73.20.1 Inhibition of all electrical Diagnostic Instances
� General Information
The inhibition conditions of the electrical diagnosis are checked. The ?ag LV_INH_DIAG_NEUT_GEAR_DPS pro-
vides this information.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: - -
Activation: always
Deactivation: never
Recurrence: 100 ms
� Function Description
if(1) LV_IGK == 1 //diagnosis is performed
then(1) LV_INH_DIAG_NEUT_GEAR_DPS = 0
ACTION_INFR_GetElDiagNGearRls(ERR_DIAG_NEUT_GEAR_RLS, CDN_DIAG_NEUT_GEAR_RLS)
else(1) LV_INH_DIAG_NEUT_GEAR_DPS = 1 //diagnosis is not performed
endif(1)

73.20.5 Range Check of Signal from Neutral Gear Sensor - High range check
� General Information
The purpose is to diagnose the input signal from the neutral gear detection sensor. Errors can be detected by
range-check. The diagnostic instance SIG_NEUT_GEAR_H contains one error symptom: neutral gear sensor
signal above upper limit
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: At RST & IGKON :
if(1) LV_AT == 1
then(1) ACTION_ERRM_VarCod(IN<NC_IDX_ERR_SIG_NEUT_GEAR_H>,1)
else(1) ACTION_ERRM_VarCod(IN<NC_IDX_ERR_SIG_NEUT_GEAR_H>,0)
endif(1)
Activation: LV_AT == 0
Deactivation: if activation condition not true
Recurrence: 10 ms

� General Information
The power stage "drive-train-open" is used in systems with Start/Stop function to enable an automatic start
without a gear selector in position P/N. The engine ECU generates in a separate power stage a release signal
analog to the PN-Signal.
This document describes the diagnosis of the "drive-train-open-signal".

implemented in the realization of the customer request?Funktionslastenheft f�r Kupplungsinformationsauswer-
tung und Plausibilisierung? (xxA05Xxx.00x).

73.21.2.2 PN recognition via CAN-Signal
The PN signal received via CAN is used for the diagnosis of the PN hardware signal. This information has to be
generated via the gear selector position of the automatic transmission.
A switch can be used to switch off the diagnosis (because no AT-Gear is recognized).

73.21.2.3 PN- and drive position recognition
The plausibility of the PN position is checked by comparing the hardware signal with the CAN-signal.
During the recognition of the drive position, differences between the hardware and the CAN-signal have to be
debounced because the CAN-signal can be delayed up to 500ms.
The detected drive position recognition has to be reset immediately if, at least, one of the PN signals (hardware
or CAN) is not pending OR a PN error is pending.
This function is only for diagnostic purpose. The release of the automatic start is done in the function "PN
recognition for automatic start release"

If both status "PN activated" and "PN not activated" were pending, then the PN detection is considered as
enabled.
The diagnosis is ?nished if both status were pending at least one time.

Figure 73.21.15:
73.21.2.5 Calculation of PN shortcut to plus or open circuit diagnosis
Via the switch LC_IGK_OFF_PN_DIAG_ENA it can be selected if the diagnosis runs only at ignition key on or also
during start-up and power latch.
The switch LC_PN_DIAG_AT_MOD is used to deactivate the diagnosis therefore the condition is not set, if the
switch is not activated.
The shortcut to plus or open circuit error is calculated via time and via start requests.
Via time:
If no PN hardware signal but a PN CAN-signal is pending for a given time, then the error is set.
Here the signal LV_PN_CLU_SWI_2 is used, which does not distinguish if the hardware pin is active because of
the active power stage or the PN pending. This is done because the power stage is not only active in "D" but
also in "N" and "P" to avoid a start interruption if the gear selector is switched during start.
Via start requests:
If several start requests occur but no PN hardware signal is pending, then the hardware signal can be consid-
ered as wrong.
If no PN hardware signal but a PN CAN-signal is pending and several start requests occur, then the error is
set.

Figure 73.21.20:
73.21.2.7 PN recognition for automatic start release
The automatic start release has to be generated via the hardware PN signal. The plausibility of the PN hardware
signal is checked with the PN CAN-signal. This can only be done if a valid gear selector position via CAN is
received.
If the CAN message can not be used (CAN is not yet available or CAN message errors occur), then the start
release is done only via the PN hardware signal.

� General Information
The transmission is sending its gear ratio via CAN. For vehicle cruise control and drivetrain manager functions,
a plausibility diagnosis has to be done. For this, the received gear ratio is compared with a calculated one.
The function is only executed in case of automatic transmission.

TRSM, Gearbox torque intervention
� Con?guration Data
Name Mode Coded Limits Display Limits Resolution Unit
NC_FID_TQ_GB_INTV_ENA_BAS - 0... FFFFH 0... 65535 1 -
Basic enable conditions for gearbox torque intervention
NC_FID_TQ_GB_INTV_INC_ENA - 0... FFFFH 0... 65535 1 -
Enable conditions for increasing gearbox torque intervention
� Import actions:
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(IN <PRM_FID>, OUT <PRM_LV_PRMS>)
� General Information
The gearbox torque intervention consists of two major parts. The ?rst part is the creation of a continuous
gearbox torque intervention request with neutral values in case of inactivity for fast and slow path. The second
part is the coordination of the torque based request generated in this speci?cation with the engine speed
based request from the engine speed control intervention speci?cation to provide the standardized interface
to the central torque coordination.
The main purpose of the speci?cation is to convert the intervention request coming from the gearbox control
unit via intersystem communication into a valid intervention request for the central torque coordination. The
conversion includes provision of continuous and consistent fast and slow path requests.
A second major purpose of the speci?cation is to de?ne substitute values and reactions on communication
errors and invalid signals as well as the reaction on diagnostic results.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST
Activation: always
Deactivation: never
Recurrence: 10MS

The content of the feedback bus is reduced to the few signals needed. In general it contains values of the last
recurrence. Additionally the signal names are adapted to allow clear distinction of the content of the feedback
bus from other input values.

73.23.2.2 Enable conditions
The conditions enabling a gearbox torque intervention can be structured into the basic enable conditions
that apply generally and which are part of the enable condition for increasing and decreasing interventions
respectively.
The basic enable conditions checks the correct communication with the gearbox as well as for valid values.
Invalid values are all kinds of initializations, unde?ned or erroneous states. Only gearboxes of class automatic
transmission are able to provide torque requests. A valid engine speed has to be available. To allow a smooth
engine start and a clean shutdown to power ledge, a gearbox intervention must not be effective during engine
start and when the ignition key is turned off.
Additional conditions need to be ful?lled for decreasing torque interventions. Due to a system error, there
might be a stuck request for a torque decrease. To avoid a decreasing intervention in this case, the state of
the intervention is checked to change to a value different from "decreasing request" at least once after engine
start before a decreasing intervention is allowed.
Increasing interventions are allowed only, if the enable conditions by monitoring and the diagnostic enable
conditions depending on vehicle acceleration and torque integral are ful?lled. Analogous to the decreasing
request the intervention state has to be different from "increasing request" at least once after engine start
before an increasing intervention is allowed.
Enable conditions for increasing and decreasing intervention have the same structure, such that diagnostic
and monitoring conditions can easily be added if needed e.g. for hybrid vehicles.

Figure 73.23.5:
73.23.2.3 Target state for fast intervention
The target state of the fast intervention is calculated for the intervention targeted by the gearbox, as well
as for the ramp back to the driver request after an intervention. A target intervention is allowed only if the
corresponding increase or decrease is enabled by the enable condition.
A ramp back to the driver request needs to be performed at the regular end of an intervention request by the
gearbox. An immediate step back to the driver request without a ramp is required if the enable condition is
no more given, e.g. because of a communication or due to monitoring. The end of the ramp is detected if the
intervention torque reaches or crosses the driver requested torque.
Any ramp is terminated and the intervention request by the gearbox is realized immediately if a new valid
request is sent by the gearbox.
Three separate state variables provide an overview of the intervention: One state variable shows the interven-
tion target state by the gearbox, one state variable shows the state of the ramp and both of them are combined
to give the global state variable indicating direction of target intervention and ramp.

73.23.2.4 Fast torque
The ramp towards the driver request in either direction is realized by freezing the last torque request during
regular intervention. In each recurrence, the difference between the current driver request and the status of

TRSM, Gearbox torque intervention
the ramp from the last recurrence is divided into a number of steps calculated from calibrated time. Only the
?rst step from the old ramp value towards the driver request is taken. This method does not terminate the
ramp within a given number of steps or a given time and it does not limit the torque gradient. The reason why
it is done in this quite complicated way is to create a behavior similar to the torque transient ?lter of the driver
request.
The ramp has to have at least a slope of 0.03125 Nm independent from whether it?s a ramp up or a ramp
down, even if the torque difference is small and the calibrated time is long, to assure at least a minimum ramp
gradient.
After a gearbox intervention and possibly a ramp to the driver request, the output of this function is the driver
request. This assures that a continuous direction independent fast gearbox torque request is available.

73.23.2.6 Slow torque and state
A slow gearbox torque may or may not be requested by the gearbox.
If there is no gearbox request for the slow path, the slow path is set identical to the fast path.
If there is a gearbox torque request for the fast path, the slow request is limited by the fast path in two di-
rections. As the limitation is imposed by the combustion engine internals, the limitation has to be done on
indicated torque basis and all values have to be transformed into indicated engine torque. The lower limit for
the slow indicated torque request is the fast indicated torque request, corresponding to a ?ltered ignition angle
ef?ciency one. The upper limit for the slow request is the fast indicated torque request divided by the mini-
mum ignition angle ef?ciency. Any torque higher than the fast torque request can be deleted by decreasing
ignition angle ef?ciency.
In analogy to the fast path a continuous slow gearbox torque request is always available.
If realization of decreasing gearbox interventions via slow path torque reduction is not enabled by calibration or
via speci?c activation, another limitation of the slow torque to be greater or equal to the fast path is applied.
For the fast intervention, the target state is known in advance. This is not true for the slow intervention. The state
of the slow torque intervention is calculated depending on the slow torque and the driver request.

73.23.2.7 Coordination of torque based and engine speed based intervention
The coordination subsystem serves the following three purposes:
Providing the interface to the central torque coordination and coordination of the torque and engine speed
based gearbox requests on torque level as well as on status level.
The interface to the global torque coordinator consists of separate values for increasing and decreasing torque
requests at clutch for both the slow and the fast path. As the gearbox is only affected by torque at clutch,
not indicated torque, the coordination is designated to use torque at clutch values. The indicated torque
values are calculated for backward compatibility and to avoid their calculation in consuming functions. Using a
separate request for increasing in combination with a maximum selection inside the coordination ensures that
a request designated to be increasing only becomes active, if it really is an increasing request. To distinguish
whether a request is increasing or decreasing, a reference torque is necessary. As there always is a delay
due to communication between engine and gearbox control unit, gearbox and engine usually have different
reference torques, leading to different categorizations as increasing or decreasing. As a consequence of the
different categorizations, some of the requests are not realized. Depending on the desired behavior this is an
advantage or a disadvantage.
The fast, direction-independent, torque is categorized as increasing or decreasing request to the central torque
coordination depending on the corresponding state that is requested by the gearbox. If the state of the fast
torque request provided by the gearbox is decreasing, then the fast torque request sent by the gearbox will not
become effective as an increasing torque, even if it is much higher than all other current torque requests inside
the coordination.
The slow, direction-independent, torque is categorized as increasing or decreasing request to the central
torque coordination as well. The important difference to the fast path however is, that the categorization is
done by comparison to the current driver request. The same driver request is used inside the central torque
coordination. Therefore the state of the slow torque request is calculated by comparison to the driver request.
It is not available as a gearbox request.
All decreasing torque requests are limited to stay above a minimum preventing from engine stalling.
All indicated torque values are limited to positive values.

The important difference to the fast path however is, that the categorization is
done by comparison to the current driver request. The same driver request is used inside the central torque
coordination. Therefore the state of the slow torque request is calculated by comparison to the driver request.
It is not available as a gearbox request.
All decreasing torque requests are limited to stay above a minimum preventing from engine stalling.
All indicated torque values are limited to positive values.

TRSM, Gearbox torque intervention
The common state of torque based and engine speed based gearbox intervention is set to "no request" if
neither of the requests is present. Any increasing request is dominant over decreasing requests, leading to a
common state "increasing request" for contradictory requests as well as for at least one increasing request. In
all other cases the common state is "decreasing request".

� Import actions:
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(IN <PRM_FID>, OUT <PRM_LV_PRMS>)
� General Information
For improved comfort and shifting performance, an increased engine torque can be requested during a gear
shift operation. This request can be sent by the gearbox control unit or internally calculated. The request
consists in a status ?ag, the targeted engine rpm and the required synchronization time. If this request is sent
by the gearbox control unit, then the usual safeguards to ensure safe communication (messages counters,
etc.) are used. They are implemented in the CAN communication interface module and are not repeated
here.
Upon reception of the request, some checks are carried out to ensure that all required de?ned conditions
have been met. Once this check has been performed, the request is considered safe and the engine speed
controller is activated.
After the engine speed controller has been activated, the targeted engine speed and the difference between
current engine speed and the target are calculated.
These values are provided to a fast and a slow controller that determine the necessary torque to ful?ll the
transmission s engine speed request.
This module must be calculated before "Gearbox torque intervention".
Con?guration bytes
Via the con?guration bytes various parts of the functionality can be turned on and off. There is a separate
con?guration byte for each type of gearbox.

TRSM, Gearbox engine speed control
The con?guration byte is de?ned as follows:
Bit Function when bit set to 1
0 not used
1 not used
2 not used
3 not used
4 Disable decrement path
5 Use TQ_DRIV_GB_INTV for pre-control
6 Use TQ_CONV for pre-control
7 Slow path controller uses the ?nal value for target speed (no ramping)

Figure 73.24.4:
73.24.2.2 Gearbox engine speed control enable conditions
The controller may only override (reduce) the driver request for a limited time. In case of low vehicle speed
this time is dependant on transmission oil temperature.
The received CAN signals are checked for errors. If a problem is detected the engine speed controller is
disabled.
The engine speed setpoint for gearbox can not become smaller than the powertrain speed setpoint (= idle
speed setpoint for combustion engines).
Additional conditions must be met before the controller can be active again. These additional conditions also
apply for the ?rst activation of the controller.

� Data De?nition
Name Mode Coded Limits Display Limits Resolution Unit
LV_GB_NCTL_MT O/V 0... 1H 0 ...1 1 -
Engine speed setpoint for manual gearbox is requested
LV_GB_NCTL_MT_ENA V 0... 1H 0 ...1 1 -
Gearbox engine speed control for manual transmission is enabled
LV_GB_NCTL_MT_INT_ENA V 0... 1H 0 ...1 1 -
Engine speed setpoint for manual gearbox is internally enabled
LV_GB_NCTL_MT_INT_SUP V 0... 1H 0 ...1 1 -
Manual transmission target engine speed control for shift up assistance is active
N_GB_NCTL_MT O/V 0... 1FE0H 0... 8160 1 rpm
Engine speed setpoint for manual gearbox
N_GB_NCTL_MT_CONT V 0... 1FE0H 0... 8160 1 rpm
Continuous manual transmission target engine speed control set-point
N_GB_NCTL_MT_COR_AC V 0... 1FE0H 0... 8160 1 rpm
Acceleration impact corrected manual transmission target engine speed control set-point
N_GB_NCTL_MT_DIF_AC V 0... 1FE0H 0... 8160 1 rpm
Difference to be added to continuous engine target speed for correction by vehicle acceleration impact
N_GB_NCTL_MT_INT V 0... 1FE0H 0... 8160 1 rpm
Internal engine speed setpoint for manual gearbox
N_GB_NCTL_MT_INT_CORD V 0... 1FE0H 0... 8160 1 rpm
Coordinated manual transmission target engine speed control set-point

� General Information
Similar to the engine speed synchronization during gear shift for automatic transmission, it is possible to create
an engine speed setpoint internally to the engine control unit for manual transmission when the vehicle is
equipped with the gear position sensor (sensor to determine continously the current position of the manual
gear lever). The engine speed setpoint for manual gearbox is calculated inside this application incidences
module and is used into the engine speed control for gearbox module.

73.25.2 Standard operation
The functionality executed during standard operation consists in the calculation of an enabling condition for
the engine speed setpoint and in the calculation of the engine speed setpoint itself.
73.25.2.1 Internal enable conditions
The engine speed setpoint for manual gearbox is internally enabled after the check of a series of conditions
based on the relevant input variables.
Remark: the validity ?ag of the gear position sensor is delayed when it falls down in order to catch signal
toggling: this timer could be removed if it is ensured that the validity ?ag does not toggle.

Figure 73.25.3:
73.25.2.2 Enable conditions
The enabling bit for the consideration of the engine speed setpoint for manual transmission is mainly in?u-
enced by the values of the clutch and accelerator pedals and by the recognization of a gear shift (it is also
possible to consider only the recognization of gear shift down to set the enabling bit).
Additionally, it is possible to inhibit the function for some gear positions (for example in case of error or inter-
mediate value of the gear position sensor).

Figure 73.25.4:
73.25.2.3 Intermediate engine speed setpoint for manual gearbox
Based on wheel rotational speed and the information for the gear position sensor, it is possible to calculate the
engine speed target at the end of the gear shifting (it means when the driver is depressing the clutch pedal).
For shift up or shift down different engine speed targets are calculated. This is because if the actual engine
speed is higher than the target, engine speed should decrease in a controlled way. If actual engine speed is
below target, target engine speed control should start during releasing the clutch.

Figure 73.25.5:
73.25.2.4 Clutch pedal scaling
The actual clutch pedal value is scaled to the range between the maximum of clutch pedal value and the
calibrated value of the clutch pedal for closed drive train. This scaling ratio is needed for determining, if a shift
up or a shift down is performed and to ramp up the engine speed setpoint to target speed.
Depending on the selected driving mode, the use of the scaling ratio to ramp up can be disabled to make the
function more spontaneous (setpoint speed = target speed).

73.25.2.5 Calculation of coordinated target engine speed control
Manual transmission target engine speed control for shift up assistance is activated, if a gear change is de-
tected and manual transmission target engine speed control is enabled and Manual transmission target engine
speed control for shift up assistance is enabled by logical calibration.
Manual transmission target engine speed control for shift up assistance is deactivated, if actual engine speed
falls under the usual manual transmission target engine speed or actual engine speed falls under a threshold
while the clutch is depressed.

73.25.2.6 Final value of engine speed setpoint for manual gearbox
The scaling ratio of actual clutch pedal value and the maximum, RATIO_PV_CLU_ACT_MAX_GB_NCTL_MT, is
used for ramping up engine speed set-point to target speed N_GB_NCTL_MT_INT_CORD. The more the clutch
is released the lower will be RATIO_PV_CLU_ACT_MAX_GB_NCTL_MT.
Once the clutch is released until to the calibrated value of the clutch pedal for closed drive train, RATIO_PV_
CLU_ACT_MAX_GB_NCTL_MT will reach zero and N_GB_NCTL_MT will reach N_GB_NCTL_MT_INT_CORD.

Figure 73.25.8:
73.25.2.7 Activation conditions
To protect the engine from damage and to ensure a proper behavior of the function, this will not be activated
when the calculated engine speed set-point calculated excess a calibrateable value or when it falls below the
idle speed value.
For shift down the functionality will be activated only when the difference between the current engine speed
during gear shift and the calculated engine speed target excess a calibrateable threshold.
For shift up the functionality will be activated, if actual engine speed is higher than the coordinated target
engine speed set-point by an offset. This offset must not be higher than the offset used to determine if a shift
up is performed.

73.26.2.4 Limitation and output
The controller output is limited on indicated torque basis to prevent from unrealistic high values. The limitation
takes engine speed and higher friction at low temperature into account. If the intervention is enabled, the
limited controller output is made the resulting torque increase request.

TRSM, Converter torque
� Import actions:
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(IN <PRM_FID>, OUT <PRM_LV_PRMS>)
� General Information
The converter torque describes the engine load (hydraulic torque losses inside the converter of an automatic
gearbox) because of the automatic transmission. Its value is received from the ETCU via CAN message and
added to the pre control of the torque structure.
The converter torque adaptation is calculated in the idle speed adaptation module and is considered to get a
higher precision of the precontrol.
TQ_TRANS_PCTL is the transmission input torque used for precontrol in idle. For automatic transmission TQ_
TRANS_PTCL is equal to the converter torque. For manual transmission and closed clutch TQ_TRANS_PCTL is
calculated from a temperature dependent map which shall represent the transmission input torque required
to turn the transmission countershaft for open drivetrain (vehicle standing, no gear engaged). For manual
transmission and open clutch this torque is equal to zero.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST, IGKON
Activation: always
Deactivation: never
Recurrence: 10MS
� Function Description

TRSM, Converter torque
73.27.2.6 Calculation of modelled converter torque
The converter torque describes the hydraulic torque losses inside the torque converter of an automatic gear-
box. They are due to the speed difference between the converter turbine and pump.
In order to assist the idle speed controller, the converter torque model is calculated in reference to the idle
speed setpoint. As a result, the modelled converter torque is bigger than the real converter torque for N <N_
SP_IS and smaller for N>N_SP_IS.

This calculation in?uences the activation of both torque model and torque reserve.

73.27.2.6.3 Gear disengagement detection for modelled converter torque
For vehicles equipped with automatic transmission with converter, an engaged gear during standing phase means max-
imum converter torque loss (because the turbine speed on gearbox side is 0rpm).
To reduce the losses and to save fuel, newer gearbox control units disengage the gear during standing phases
and re-engage it when the driver starts leaving the brake pedal or switch the gear lever to another driving
position than D (especially R, TIP or SPT).
Depending on vehicle speed and ratio between converter turbine speed over engine idle speed, it is possible
to detect a gear disengagement phase in order to switch the converter torque model to P/N conditions.

TRSM, Converter torque
Depending on vehicle speed, gear lever position and brake pressure, it is possible to detect a deactivated gear
disengagement phase in order to switch on the converter torque reserve (because the converter torque losses
is rising quickly again and the converter torque reserve allows to avoid engine speed drops). In order to build
up the torque reserve quickly, this detection uses driver information (gear lever, brake pressure) rather than
converter information (ratio between turbine speed and engine speed).

73.27.2.6.4 Converter torque model activation

Each time the activation state of the modelled converter torque changes, its current value is stored for later
use and a timer is initialised.

Figure 73.27.21:
73.27.2.6.5 Ramping factor for modelled converter torque
A factor to ramp the converter torque at drivetrain engaged transitions (OFF<->ON) is calculated here.
Calibration hints:
The ramping factor depends on the time elapsed since the last drivetrain engaged transition. This time is reset
to its maximum value at transition: to use its full range, the time axis for calibration maps shall start from the
maximal timer value and ends to 0.
The ramping is realized in the subsystem "Modelled converter torque": it starts from an hold value and ends to
a target value. for this reason, the ramping factor shall starts from 0 (at maximum timer value) and ends to 1
(at minimum timer value).

TRSM, Converter torque
73.27.2.6.6 Target value of modelled converter torque
The target value of the modelled converter torque for driving conditions is calculated as a function of the idle
engine speed setpoint.
The target value of the modelled converter torque for park/neutral conditions is output from an oil temperature
based map.
In order to use the turbine speed information even in park/neutral conditions, it is possible to use the modelled
converter torque for driving conditions for a certain time after transition from drivetrain engaged to drivetrain
disengaged. A threshold depending on the ramping factor value is used as switch condition.
Calibration hints:
If the converter turbine speed to idle speed ratio is almost 1 due to drivetrain disengaged by car stand-still, the
modelled converter torque should deliver a value near 0, otherwise a wrong compensation would be done
in
the idle speed adaptation.
If the converter speed to idle speed ratio is almost 1 while car brakes, then the modelled converter torque
should deliver a high positive value to avoid a drop in engine speed.

TRSM, Converter torque
73.27.2.6.7 Modelled converter torque
If the converter torque model is on, then it is ramped towards the target value for driving conditions based
on the calibratable ramping factor for driving conditions.
If the converter torque model is considered off, then it is ramped towards the target value for park/neutral
conditions based on the calibratable ramping factor for park neutral conditions.
Calibration hint:
Both ramps can be delayed by calibrating the factor on 0 for the ?rst steps of the ramp, effectively freezing the
modelled converter torque on its stored value.

Figure 73.27.25:
73.27.2.6.9 Converter torque reserve activation
The converter torque reserve is on if a rising edge of drivetrain engaged is detected or if the gear disengage-
ment deactivation is detected.
The converter torque reserve is off if a falling edge of drivetrain engaged is detected or if the maximum time
for converter torque reserve elapsed.
Each time the activation state of the converter torque reserve changes, its current value is stored for later use
and a timer is initialised.

Figure 73.28.2:
73.28.2 Standard operation
The functionality executed during standard operation is to generate the central output Torque reserve for
transmission, which is an input to the torque reserve coordination.
73.28.2.1 Feedback adaption
73.28.2.2 Enable conditions
The torque reserve for transmission is enabled when the gear lever is in driving position, the accelerator pedal
is pressed and the vehicle speed is lower than a maximum threshold.
The torque reserve for transmission due to drive off is enabled when the gear lever is in driving position
and the vehicle speed is lower than a maximum threshold but not zero (condition deactivatable in order to
allow a torque reserve at stopped vehicle just before drive off).
If the vehicle speed is higher than the maximum threshold, then it means that the vehicle is in regular driving
mode and both enable conditions are deactivated.

73.28.2.3 Timer reset
The activation time of torque reserve for transmission is held on zero (i.e. the timer is disabled) if:
- the gear lever is in park neutral OR
- the enable condition of torque reserve for transmission is active OR
- the enable condition of torque reserve for transmission due to drive off is active OR the vehicle speed is
higher than the maximum threshold. These two conditions are merged as: ?vehicle speed not null?.
If the conditions for holding the timer on zero are not active, then the reset value of the timer is given by an oil
temperature dependent map.
The timer is reset when the gear lever exits park neutral and the vehicle speed becomes 0 or when the brake
is released.

73.28.2.4 Activation of torque reserve for transmission
If the torque reserve for transmission enable conditions are active, then it is activated directly and the activation
timer is held on zero. Otherwise, the reset of the timer occurs as described in the previous chapter and the
torque reserve for transmission is active for as long as the timer counts down.

Calibration hint:
If the torque is to return to the maximal value instantaneously, the ramping up step have to be calibrated with
1023,97 Nm.

TRSM, Coasting
� Import actions:
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(IN <PRM_FID>, OUT <PRM_LV_PRMS>)
� General Information
The coordinated information, if coasting can be enabled from the engine control unit?s point of view is provided
to the gearbox by this function. It is sent to the gearbox via intersystem communication. The gearbox takes this
coasting enable condition, coordinates it with coasting enable conditions from other sources and it?s internal
calculation and decides to coast ? or not.
The gearbox permanently communicates it?s state to the engine control unit. One of the possible states of
the gearbox is coasting. The behavior of many engine functions - including the behavior of this functionality
- changes if the gearbox is in state ?Coasting?. For easy handling a ?ag ?Coasting is active? is generated inside
this speci?cation and provided to all engine functions.
Calibration offers the features to
1. Ignore enable conditions separately
2. Ignore all enable conditions, thus permanently enable coasting independently of the engine state
3. Permanently inhibit coasting
The main condition for coasting is an actual and predicted clutch torque around 0 Nm for a particular time.
During coast phase the transmission internal clutches are open or the gear is physically disengaged, such
that no torque is transmitted to the wheels. The driver request is suppressed but observed and the engine
speed is controlled by the idle speed controller. The setpoint for the idle speed controller depends on vehicle
conditions.
To be able to decide when to terminate coasting and re-engage the clutch, the engine sends the predicted
torque at clutch to the transmission control unit.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST
Activation: always
Deactivation: never
Recurrence: 10MS

73.30.2 Standard operation
The functionality is split into three categories:
1. Determination of the ?ag for the gearbox state ?Coasting is active? as it is used also inside this speci?ca-
tion.
2. Calculation of the complex enable conditions depending on
a. Energy management in general
b. Energy management in conjunction with the air conditioning compressor
c. Canister load
d. Lambda sensor diagnosis
This is done in separate subsystems to keep the overview.
3. Combination of simple and complex enable conditions to the overall ?Coasting is enabled? by the engine
control unit for communication to the gearbox.
Functionalities like the lambda sensor diagnosis need the pull phases to run completely, the driver does not
requests a coast-inhibition by pushbutton, the cruise control doesn?t determines a too high vehicle speed
deviation to its set point, the canister load is below a maximum threshold (activated carbon canister needs
higher purge rates), energy management or engine roughness adaptation process doesn?t request a higher
engine speed than idle.

73.30.2.3 Energy management enables coasting
The energy management of the vehicle can enable and inhibit coasting. As suf?cient energy is obligatory for
vehicle operation suf?cient energy has priority over coasting.
Additionally, changes in the engine state, explicitly changes in coasting, should be obvious to the driver, e.g.
because they are related to driving situations. Energy management however is not obvious to the driver, so
changes due to engery management need to be restricted to a minimum.
If energy management enables coasting, this can be done
1. without a request to keep a certain minimum engine speed and thus a minimum power supply
2. with a request to keep a
a. minimum engine speed on a lower level
b. minimum engine speed on a higher level
With the higher of the engine speeds all possible energy needs are covered.
File: 7ED04501.00B
26212Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

Copyright �Continental AG. Transmittal, reproduction, dissemination and/or editing of this document as well as utilisation of its contents and communication thereof to others without
expressed authorisation are prohibited. Offenders will be held liable for payment of damages. All rights created by patent grant or registration of a utility model or design patent are reserved.
TRSM, Coasting
Once coasting is active the energy management can only keep or increase the minimum requested engine
speed ? if any ? during that coasting instance. This is to avoid changes in engine speed without safety necessity
and without obvious reason for the driver.
To not irritate the driver energy management cannot terminate a coasting phase.
Calibration hints
To in?uence the system?s reaction on different engine speed requests by energy management, adapt the map

73.30.2.4 Lambda sensor diagnosis enables coasting
Functionalities like lambda sensor diagnosis need the pull phases to run completely.
Normally coasting would be inhibited in pull phases until the diagnosis is completed, because coasting termi-
nates pull phases by opening the clutch. If other conditions like insuf?cient lambda sensor voltage would not
allow a diagnosis even if there is a pull phase, there is no reason to inhibit coasting. This condition to enable
coasting is calculated here.

73.30.2.6 Air conditioning and energy management enables coasting
Coasting is enabled, if neither energy management nor air conditioning control unit request a minimum en-
gine speed. Otherwise coasting is enabled only, if the engine speed is above a given threshold, including a
hysteresis to avoid toggling.
Once coasting is active, the original request for a minimum engine speed is no more considered.
The relevant power supply to the vehicle is then assured via the energy only enable condition, which is found
in another subsystem of this speci?cation.
